questions.question_text: What function does VXLAN perform in a Cisco SD-Access deployment?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct
VXLAN Does data plane forwarding whereas LISP does control plane forwarding

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
voting. provided answer is correct

comments.content:
They are asking the three components of SDA (SD-Access) Overlay Network Layer:
A. policy plane forwarding (SDA Fabric Policy Plane) -> Cisco TrusSec SGT tags
B. control plane forwarding (SDA Fabric Control Plane) -> LISP
C. data plane forwarding (SDA Fabric Data Plane) -> VXLAN

discussion.content: The given answer is correct

questions.question_text: Which Python library is used to work with YANG data models via NETCONF?

discussion.content:

Given answer is correct.
Python files usually start with "from ncclient import manager"

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
ncclient is python library that facilitate NETCONF

questions.question_text:
SIMULATION
-


Guidelines
-

This is a lab item in which tasks will be performed on virtual devices.

• Refer to the Tasks tab to view the tasks for this lab item.
• Refer to the Topology tab to access the device console(s) and perform the tasks.
• Console access is available for all required devices by clicking the device icon or using the tab(s) above the console window.
• All necessary preconfigurations have been applied.
• Do not change the enable password or hostname for any device.
• Save your configurations to NVRAM before moving to the next item.
• Click Next at the bottom of the screen to submit this lab and move to the next question.
• When Next is clicked, the lab closes and cannot be reopened.


Topology
-

//IMG//



Tasks
-

The operations team started configuring network devices for a new site.
Complete the configurations to achieve these goals:
1. Ensure that port channel Po1 between DISTRO-SW01 and DISTRO-SW02 is operational using the LACP protocol. Configuration changes for this task must be made on DISTRO-SW01.
2. Ensure that traffic on VLAN 10 is carried as untagged traffic between DISTRO-SW01 and DISTRO-SW02.
3. Complete the Rapid-PVST+ configuration on DISTRO-SW2 by ensuring it it the secondary root switch for all VLANs in the range of 1 to 1005.


DISTRO-SW01
-

//IMG//


//IMG//


//IMG//


//IMG//



DISTRO-SW02
-

//IMG//


//IMG//


//IMG//

discussion.content:
Distro-SW01
#int po1
#switchport mode trunk
#switchport trunk native vlan 10

#int e0/2
#channel-group 1 mode active
#int e0/3
#channel-group 1 mode active

Distro-SW02
#int po1
 #switchport mode trunk
 #switchport trunk native vlan 10

#spanning-tree mode rapid-pvst
#spanning-tree vlan 1-1005 root secondary

sw01

int e0/0
no channel-group 1
int range e0/2-3
channel-group 1 mode active


sw1
interface port-channel 1
switchport trunk native vlan 10


sw2
interface port-channel 1
switchport trunk native vlan 10
interface port-channel 1
spanning-tree vlan 1-1005 root secondary

comments.content: need to have switchport mode trunk, if not your native vlan wrong establish

discussion.content:
DSW1: conf t
 int range e0/2 -3
 channel-group1 mode active
 int po1 
 switchport mode trunk
 switchport trunk encapsulation dot1q
 switchport trunk native vlan 10
DSW2: conf t
 int range e0/2 -3 
 channel-group1 mode active
 int po1 
 switchport mode trunk
 switchport trunk encapsulation dot1q
 switchport trunk native vlan 10
 exit
 spanning-tree mode rapid-pvst
 spanning-tree vlan 1-1005 root secondary

comments.content: ...so check your status port change and then copy run start

discussion.content:
If you just config root secondary on SW2, it will be root (lab in CML)

DISTRO-SW1(config)#spanning-tree vlan 1-1005 root primary

That makes SW1 have a config output of "spanning-tree vlan 1-1005 priority 24576"
this command is not working for me spanning-tree vlan 1-1005 root secondary

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network architect has partially configured static NAT. Which commands should be added to complete the configuration?

choices.B:
R1(config)# interface GigabitEthernet 0/0

R1(config)# ip pat outside -
R1(config)# interface GigabitEthernet 0/1

R1(config)# ip pat inside -
choices.A:
R1(config)# interface GigabitEthernet 0/0

R1(config)# ip pat inside -
R1(config)# interface GigabitEthernet 0/1

R1(config)# ip pat outside -
choices.D:
R1(config)# interface GigabitEthernet 0/0

R1(config-if)# ip nat outside -
R1(config)# interface GigabitEthernet 0/1
R1(config-if)# ip nat inside
choices.C:
R1(config)# interface GigabitEthernet 0/0

R1(config-if)# ip nat inside -
R1(config)# interface GigabitEthernet 0/1

R1(config-if)# ip nat outside -

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct. There is no such thing as 'ip pat inside/outside'.

Selected Answer: D
The example above uses static NAT.
PAT is a form of dynamic NAT, where hosts share the same public IP address.

To configure PAT:
(1) we need to create a source list for the private IPs we want to convert
(2) map this list to an interface configured with a public IP or to a pool of public IPs.

- We can distinguish between the different sessions by assigning a port number for each session, while still allowing all hosts to share the same public IP address.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
answer B is correct

Selected Answer: D
Configure the inside static NAT by using the command "ip nat inside source
static inside-local-ip inside-global-ip." . First is inside local ip = 10.78.9.7 (ge0/1)

Selected Answer: D
there's no "ip pat inside" command :)

comments.content: Clue is in refer to the exhibit and also as NewLife77 mentioned, ip pat inside/outside isnt a command that is valid

discussion.content:
A is the answer
Gi0/0 is translating the inside local addresses on Gi0/1 into the outside global pool of addresses D is not correct

choices.A:
R1(config)# access-list 120 permit tcp 172.16.1.0 0.0.0.255 21 172.16.2.0 0.0.0.255

R1 (config)#interface giga 0/2 -
R1 (config-if)#ip access-group 120 in
choices.C:
R1 (config)# access-list 120 deny any any
R1(config)# access-list 120 permit tcp 172.16.1.0 0.0.0.255 172.16.2.0 0.0.0.255 21

R1 (config)#interface giga 0/0 -
R1(config-if)#ip access-group 120 out
choices.B:
R1(config)# access-list 120 permit tcp 172.16.1.0 0.0.0.255 172.16.2.0 0.0.0.255 20
R1(config)# access-list 120 permit tcp 172.16.1.0 0.0.0.255 172.16.2.0 0.0.0.255 21

R1(config)#interface giga 0/2 -
R1 (config-if)#ip access-group 120 in
choices.D:
R1(config)# access-list 120 permit tcp 172.16.1.0 0.0.0.255 21 172.16.2.0 0.0.0.255
R1(config)# access-list 120 permit udp 172.16.1.0 0.0.0.255 21 172.16.2.0 0.0.0.255

R1 (config)#interface giga 0/2 -
R1(config-if)#ip access-group 120 out

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer must allow the FTP traffic from users on 172.16.1.0 /24 to 172.16.2.0 /24 and block all other traffic. Which configuration must be applied?

comments.content: They forgot to include the "eq" keyword

discussion.content: Query: in answer B why dont they put eq 21 or eq 20 before port number

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Example given for active FTP:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/access-lists/26448-ACLsamples.html#toc-hId--437118599

Selected Answer: B
Has to be B, ftp 'active mode' uses port 21 for control and 20 for data, both are TCP. ftp in passive mode will use a random port instead of 20 for data, typical is 1024 to 65535.
